sections.summary: Allah is glorified for sending down the **Criterion** upon His servant to warn humanity, affirming His absolute **Sovereignty** as the sole Creator who has neither partner nor son.

Disbelievers dismiss the Quran as fabricated legends and mock the Prophet for his mortal needs, such as eating food and walking in markets. Allah identifies these claims as a manifest injustice and evidence that the detractors have gone astray.

Those who deny the **Hour** are prepared for a raging **Blaze**, while the righteous are promised the **Garden of Eternity** as a binding promise. On the Day of Judgment, false deities will be questioned and will disavow their followers, acknowledging that only Allah is the Lord [465–466].

Messengers are sent as mortals to test human **patience**, and on the Day of Resurrection, the sky will be cleft with clouds as angels descend. The wrongdoer will bite his hands in regret for following bad companions and abandoning the **Message** of the Messenger [466–467].

The Quran was revealed in stages rather than all at once to strengthen the Prophet’s heart. Allah provides the **Truth** and the best exposition to counter any argument brought by those herded into Hell.

The text references the destruction of previous nations, such as the people of Noah, Aad, and Thamood, who rejected their messengers. It likens heedless disbelievers to cattle, noting they are even further astray for taking their own **desires** as their god.

Allah manifests His power through natural phenomena, including the movement of **shadows**, the alternation of night and day, and the creation of humanity from **fluid**. These signs, including the merging of the two seas and the constellations in the sky, are meant to inspire **gratitude** and reflection [468–469].

The **Servants of the Merciful** are identified by their humility, night prayers, and avoidance of **shirk, murder, and adultery**. Those who offer sincere **repentance** and work righteousness will have their bad deeds replaced with good and inherit the Chamber as a reward for their **patience** [469–470].
